seg.seg: the teeth extremely even, without gap and [close?] together. 23rd mark. ///
the jaws [are] broad, firm and round like those of a Kesarin lion. 25th mark. ///
the slender, large tongue covering all the moon of the face to the (front) ///
generating great pleasure and delight, the joy of the listeners
(29). || Eye-lashes like those of the king of the yak-bulls
a wisp of hair, extremely white and beautiful, turned towards the right
(looking) at this body of the master, the Buddha, adorned with 32 marks
This one (equipped with such a body) is the refuge and the protection, the master of all the world. If only I could have a body of that kind, too!
(all the way) down, with the 32 marks ///
he regards closely [the body of the Buddha], and after having regarded [it] truly closely, he thinks ///

p.note: This fragment contains part of the twenty-sixth act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka. An Uy. parallel would be MaitrHami 26, Blatt Bv-Cr, but see 204.
The fragment partly overlaps with, and is immediately followed by, (line b6 here = a1).
Fragment of a manuscript which includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. 64-65). Lines a1 and b8 are lost.
the line is lost, but must have contained the 15th and 16th mark of the Buddha (for this and the following, cf. 212-224).
Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b2-3.
Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b7-8.

Parallel passage: ?MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b13-14, which refers to the perfect order of the Buddha's teeth, which neither slant to the inside nor protrude - actually mark 23 (but see line a5 and note a5 below). In this case one would have to supplement line a4 with mā a(nne mā pärne ṣtmoṣ kamañ).
Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b14. It is not unlikely that the marks concerning the teeth, particularly 22 and 23 are merged in this list.
Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b17-18.
27th mark. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b21-22.
28th mark. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b23-27.
Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a1-2. The number 9 at the beginning of this line is the remnant of a number 29, referring to the previous mark.
32nd mark. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a4-8.
Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a8-9. From here on the text is concerned with the thoughts of King Siṃha.
Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a18-21.

There is no real parallel passage, but cf. MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a21-23, about king Siṃha having regarded the 32 marks with rapt attention. 222-3 suggests the restauration (ā)ñc 'downward' for the passage to mean something along the lines of “regarding the 32 marks from head to toe”.
Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a21-24 and a1.

This fragment contains part of the twenty-sixth act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka. An Uy. parallel would be MaitrHami 26, Blatt Bv-Cr, but see [[Pinault 1999]]: 204.

The fragment partly overlaps with, and is immediately followed by, [[A 307]] (line b6 here = [[A 307]] a1).

a1 the line is lost, but must have contained the 15th and 16th mark of the Buddha (for this and the following, cf. [[Pinault 1999]]: 212-224).

a2. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b2-3.

a3. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b7-8.

a4. Parallel passage: ?MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b13-14, which refers to the perfect order of the Buddha's teeth, which neither slant to the inside nor protrude - actually mark 23 (but see line a5 and note a5 below). In this case one would have to supplement line a4 with mā a(nne mā pärne ṣtmoṣ kamañ).

a5. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b14. It is not unlikely that the marks concerning the teeth, particularly 22 and 23 are merged in this list.

a6. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b17-18.

a7. 27th mark. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b21-22.

a8. 28th mark. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. B, b23-27.

b1. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a1-2. The number 9 at the beginning of this line is the remnant of a number 29, referring to the previous mark.

b2. 32nd mark. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a4-8.

b3. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a8-9. From here on the text is concerned with the thoughts of King Siṃha.

b4. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a18-21.

b5. There is no real parallel passage, but cf. MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a21-23, about king Siṃha having regarded the 32 marks with rapt attention. [[Pinault 1999]]: 222-3 suggests the restauration (ā)ñc 'downward' for the passage to mean something along the lines of “regarding the 32 marks from head to toe”.

b6. Parallel passage: MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, a21-24 and [[A 307]] a1.

b7. See the parallel passage, [[A 307]] a1-2.
